name: Microgreens
notes: Fastest ROI, perfect for Bay Area restaurants, low water usage, indoor/greenhouse production

name: Sunflower Shoots
notes: Highest profit microgreen, nutty flavor, large shoots, restaurant favorite, fast growing

name: Pea Shoots
notes: Sweet flavor, high demand, tender shoots, Asian cuisine staple, excellent margins

name: Radish Microgreens
notes: Fastest growing microgreen, spicy flavor, vibrant color, high turnover, great margins

name: Broccoli Microgreens
notes: Superfood status, health benefits, mild flavor, restaurant demand, consistent sales

name: Wheatgrass
notes: Juice bars demand, health food market, easy to grow, detox trend, year-round production

name: Basil Microgreens
notes: Premium pricing, intense flavor, chef favorite, Italian cuisine, high profit margins

name: Cilantro Microgreens
notes: Latin + Asian cuisine, strong flavor, restaurant staple, no bolting issues, consistent demand

name: Amaranth Microgreens
notes: Stunning red/purple color, nutty flavor, high nutrition, premium pricing, Instagram-worthy

name: Arugula Microgreens
notes: Peppery flavor, fast growing, salad mix staple, restaurant demand, easy to grow

name: Cannabis
commonDiseases: Powdery mildew, bud rot, root rot
notes: Requires license $50K-$200K+, heavy regulation, high competition, security required

name: Gourmet Mushrooms
notes: Indoor production, year-round harvest, high restaurant demand, controlled environment

name: Strawberries
commonDiseases: Gray mold, powdery mildew, verticillium wilt
notes: Perfect Bay Area climate, U-pick potential, agritourism, coastal fog benefits

name: Lavender
notes: Drought tolerant, value-added products (oil, soap), beautiful, low maintenance

name: Saffron
notes: Highest value spice, labor-intensive harvest, October bloom, very high price

name: Ginseng
notes: Long-term investment, requires 70-80% shade, Asian market demand, very high value

name: Goji Berries
notes: Superfood trend, drought tolerant, dual market (TCM + health), perennial

name: Culinary Herbs
notes: Basil, cilantro, mint, oregano, thyme - high restaurant demand, easy to grow

name: Bamboo
notes: Edible shoots + construction poles, invasive concerns, containment required

name: Specialty Cut Flowers
notes: Dahlias, ranunculus, peonies - high-end florist market, wedding demand

name: Astragalus
notes: Chinese medicine (Huang Qi), drought tolerant, easy to grow, Asian market

name: Reishi Mushroom
notes: Traditional Chinese medicine (Ling Zhi), controlled environment, very high value

name: Schisandra

name: Jujube

name: Turmeric
notes: Trending superfood (Jiang Huang), easy to grow, Asian + health food markets

name: Licorice

name: Chrysanthemum

name: Codonopsis

name: Shiitake Mushrooms
notes: Most popular gourmet mushroom, restaurant demand, logs or indoor cultivation

notes: Fastest growing gourmet mushroom, multiple varieties (pearl, golden, pink), easy

name: Lion's Mane

name: Maitake
notes: Hen of the Woods, medicinal properties, premium pricing, requires skill

notes: Genovese, Thai, Purple varieties, restaurant staple, high turnover, heat-loving

name: Cilantro
notes: Cool season herb, Asian + Latin cuisine, bolts in heat, succession planting

notes: Peppermint, spearmint varieties, invasive (contain), tea + cocktail demand, perennial

name: Rosemary
notes: Perennial Mediterranean herb, drought tolerant, year-round harvest, low maintenance

notes: Perennial, drought tolerant, multiple varieties, Mediterranean cuisine, low care

notes: Flat leaf (Italian) and curly, biennial, cool season, restaurant garnish staple

name: Arugula
notes: Fast-growing salad green, peppery flavor, restaurant demand, cool season crop

notes: Superfood green, multiple varieties, cold-hardy, farmers market favorite

name: Lettuce Mix
notes: Spring mix, mesclun, restaurant demand, succession planting, cool season
